lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.title: Getting Started
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.welcome: Welcome! This module generates a prep journal that follows the "Return of the Lazy Dungeon Master" flow. Using the Create GM Prep button again creates additional journals. Auto numbered journals start at 0 and increase as new ones are created.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.other-optio: Press Alt+P to create the next prep journal.
Type /prep in the chat to generate the next prep journal.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.settings.se: Separate Pages - A checkmark on this option will create a separate page for each step. With it unchecked, all steps are combined into a single page.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.settings.fo: Folder Name - The text entered into this field will be used when creating the folder where all new journals are added.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.settings.jo: Prefix - The text entered into this field will be used for the journal name.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.settings.in: Include Date - A checkmark on this option appends today's date to the journal name.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.settings.de: Starting Rows - The number entered in these fields is used for the number of rows on the Character and NPC pages
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.settings.co: Copy Previous - A checkmark on these options will copy each pages content into the next journal.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.good.title: Good to Know
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.good.secret: Secrets & Clues carry forward: Only unchecked clues from the prior session is brought forward and topped up to 10.
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.good.editab: Editable Tables: Use Foundry's table tools to add/remove rows or columns on the Character and NPC pages (not roll tables).
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.good.dragDr: Drag & Drop: Drop actors into the "Review the Characters" table for one-click access to sheets. This can be done ror NPCs and other items for any page.
lazy-gm-prep.settings.separatePages.name: Separate Pages for Each Step
lazy-gm-prep.settings.separatePages.hint: If enabled, create one page per step; otherwise combine all steps into one page.

lazy-gm-prep.steps.review-characters.des: Take a moment to refresh yourself on the names, backgrounds, motivations, and player interests for every PC. This primes your brain so the rest of your prep wraps naturally around the characters.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.strong-start.title: 2. Create a Strong Start
lazy-gm-prep.steps.strong-start.descript: Define a vivid opening that drops the party near the action—an event, hook, or immediate scene that propels the session forward. When in doubt, start with conflict.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.outline-scenes.title: 3. Outline Potential Scenes
lazy-gm-prep.steps.outline-scenes.descri: Use this page as your flexible, living roadmap—ready to adapt, improvise, and delight in the surprises your players bring. Prep just enough to feel confident, not constrained, and without overcommitting.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.secrets-clues.title: 4. Define Secrets & Clues
lazy-gm-prep.steps.secrets-clues.descrip: Secrets and clues are the connective tissue of your adventure—short, evocative facts, revelations, or mysteries that the characters might uncover as they explore. Do not tie them to a specific location or NPC, so you can reveal them wherever it makes sense.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.fantastic-locations.d: Give each place a bold, evocative name and jot down a few striking, memorable features. Focus on what makes each location unique, what’s happening there now, and how it might connect to your PCs.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.important-npcs.title: 6. Outline Important NPCs
lazy-gm-prep.steps.important-npcs.descri: Focus on the NPCs who drive the story, serve as quest-givers, major allies, rivals, or villains. Keep your notes brief—just enough to remind you of their role and how they connect to the adventure.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.choose-monsters.title: 7. Choose Relevant Monsters
lazy-gm-prep.steps.choose-monsters.descr: Pick foes that make sense for your adventure’s story and setting—focus on what’s fun and fits the moment. Treat difficulty as a loose gauge; let story and context shape the encounter.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.magic-item-rewards.de: Drop items that excite the players and tie into the story. Items can anchor secrets and become tangible hooks.
lazy-gm-prep.steps.other-notes.title: Other Notes
lazy-gm-prep.steps.other-notes.descripti: Scratch pad for reminders, marching order, pacing beats, or anything else you want at your fingertips.
lazy-gm-prep.prompts.heading: Prompts
lazy-gm-prep.characters.table.heading: Characters
lazy-gm-prep.characters.tip.prompt: Lazy Tip: Can you name every character at the table, and recall one thing about each?
lazy-gm-prep.characters.prompts.spotligh: Who hasn’t had a spotlight moment lately?
lazy-gm-prep.characters.prompts.unresolv: Does any character have an unresolved goal, secret, or personal hook to bring forward?
lazy-gm-prep.characters.prompts.bonds: Any PC bonds or rivalries to highlight this session?
lazy-gm-prep.characters.prompts.reward: Who is due for a magic item or story reward?
lazy-gm-prep.npcs.table.header.name: Name
lazy-gm-prep.getting-started.sections.re: A 2–5 word summary (e.g., “Cynical Elf Wizard,” “Brash Human Fighter”).
What does this character want? (e.g., “Find lost sister,” “Prove self to mentor,” “Get rich or die trying”).
Last session’s drama, a secret, a relationship, or a “to-do” for next session.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.card.heading: Strong Start
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.card.title: Strong Start
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.world: What’s happening in the world right now, outside the PCs’ control?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.grab: What would grab your players’ attention in the first 60 seconds?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.close: How can you start close to the action—without a long briefing?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.twist: What complication or twist could upend the party’s expectations?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.tie: How can this opening tie to a PC’s background, goal, or unresolved thread?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.mood: What mood do you want to set—chaos, mystery, danger, or wonder?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.prompts.player: If you were a player, what opening would make you lean forward?
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.heading: Strong Start Encounters
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.1: A riot erupts in the marketplace, and the party is caught in the chaos.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.2: A blood-curdling scream from a nearby alley—someone needs help.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.3: The sky darkens as a magical storm sweeps in, warping reality.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.4: A wounded messenger collapses at the party’s feet, clutching a sealed letter.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.5: The ground shakes as something massive tunnels beneath the city.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.6: A festival is interrupted by a rampaging beast or construct.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.7: A mysterious stranger offers the party a dangerous wager.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.8: The lord’s guards are searching for someone—one of the PCs fits the description.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.9: An explosion rocks a nearby building—fire and panic spread.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.10: A child begs for protection from unseen pursuers.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.11: A public execution goes wrong—the condemned escapes.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.12: An ancient artifact activates unexpectedly, drawing unwanted attention.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.13: A rival adventuring group challenges the party to a public contest.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.14: The dead rise from the graveyard as a blood moon ascends.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.15: A rain of frogs, blood, or gold coins falls from the sky—an omen or a curse.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.16: A trusted NPC betrays the party in front of a crowd.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.17: A portal opens, disgorging a confused—or hostile—creature.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.18: The party is accused of a crime they didn’t commit—guards close in.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.19: A desperate merchant offers a fortune for immediate help.
lazy-gm-prep.strong-start.table.20: The villain’s minions attack, targeting something (or someone) the party cares about.
lazy-gm-prep.secrets-clues.prompts.rumor: What rumor could change the party’s understanding of the world or reveal some of the villain's plan?
lazy-gm-prep.secrets-clues.prompts.secre: What secret from a character’s past or connection with an NPC might resurface?
lazy-gm-prep.secrets-clues.prompts.artif: What evidence or artifact could point the party toward a new location or objective?
lazy-gm-prep.secrets-clues.prompts.myste: What is a mystery about the dungeon, town, or region that could be revealed?
lazy-gm-prep.outline-scenes.heading: Scenes
lazy-gm-prep.outline-scenes.prompts.1: Aim for 1–2 scenes per hour of play.
lazy-gm-prep.outline-scenes.prompts.2: Mix scene types: include social, exploration, and combat.
lazy-gm-prep.outline-scenes.prompts.3: Don’t overcommit—three scenes are enough to feel ready.
lazy-gm-prep.outline-scenes.prompts.4: Be ready to skip, swap, or delete scenes as play evolves.
lazy-gm-prep.fantastic-locations.prompts: What senses does this place evoke? (What do you hear, smell, or feel that’s unique?)
What’s the biggest danger or opportunity here? (What could go wrong—or right?)
Who wants to control, protect, or exploit this place—and why?
What’s the weirdest or most memorable feature here, even if it’s just set dressing?
lazy-gm-prep.fantastic-locations.tip: Lazy Tip:  Don’t overthink it. One sentence per field is enough. If you need inspiration, roll on a random table or borrow from your favorite adventure.
lazy-gm-prep.npcs.prompts.connection: What is this NPC’s connection to the adventure or the characters?
lazy-gm-prep.npcs.prompts.goal: What secret, motivation, or goal drives this NPC?
lazy-gm-prep.npcs.prompts.trait: What is one unique trait, quirk, or mannerism that makes them memorable?
lazy-gm-prep.npcs.prompts.surprise: What’s one way this NPC could surprise the party?
lazy-gm-prep.monsters.prompts.1: What monsters would naturally inhabit this place? What threats or allies fit the current situation?
lazy-gm-prep.monsters.prompts.2: Are there monsters that connect to the PCs’ backgrounds or campaign secrets?
lazy-gm-prep.monsters.prompts.3: Is there a boss or unique monster that can be highlighted?
lazy-gm-prep.monsters.prompts.4: Can you reskin or modify an existing monster to fit your needs?
lazy-gm-prep.monsters.tip: Lazy Tip: List a handful of likely monsters, improvise the rest, and be ready to swap them out if the story changes.
